newsitem.title: USA: Utilities protest U.S. EPA's focus on power plants.
newsitem.headline: Utilities protest U.S. EPA's focus on power plants.

text.p: U.S. utilities complained to the Environmental Protection Agency that it had unfairly singled out power plant emissions cuts to meet proposed new clean air standards, according to a letter released Friday.

Charles Goodman, a vice president of Southern Co Services, urged EPA Administrator Carol Browner to retract statements which he said had created the impression that strict new limits on smog and soot could be met simply by cutting utility pollution.

Browner and other EPA officials had made the statements in an effort to convince lawmakers and industry groups that the standards would not require big changes in lifestyle nor the adoption of costly new technologies for cars and factories.
"Such statements are inappropriate, unwarranted and not supportable," Goodman said in the June 12 letter to Browner, sent on behalf of the Utility Air Regulatory Group.
The letter said that "focusing a control strategy for the proposed (National Ambient Air Quality Standards) solely on utility power plants would be neither effective nor fair."
EPA last November proposed to tighten standards for smog-forming ozone and particulates. The White House is now reviewing the controversial plan before a final rule is issued in July.

Modeling by a 37-state ozone assessment group set up by EPA found that even if utilities cut all of their nitrogen oxide emissions, many areas would still not be able to meet the current ozone standards, let alone tighter restrictions.

The effect of controlling utility emissions to limit particulate matter was even more questionable, Goodman said, citing high levels of soot in California, where power plants area already subject to tight pollution controls.
